values:
God is consuming the planet itself. 

We have until sunrise to stop it, or every living creature remaining in this accursed world will be dead.

We have decided to try to get to the EGG Facility. Perhaps Sera can get God's attention. Perhaps she can change God's mind.

It is our only hope now.

Farewell.

The Junkyard isn't like most worlds, though the differences won't necessarily be noticeable to everyone who goes there. However, I strongly advise anyone planning on visiting Gale to read this post first, to make sure it doesn't affect your character. What is the Junkyard? The Junkyard is actually an extremely sophisticated battle simulation program, and the people who live there are computer-generated soldiers. The purpose of the Junkyard is to determine the best methods, skills, etc. for war, I believe the idea was that once that was determined through the simulation, that that program would be imported into real people, to turn them into super soldiers. Therefore, the Junkyard is a place of constant battle. There are compounds scattered through the location, filled with soldiers who can turn into bloodthirsty, cannibalistic demons who will rip your throat out. Outside of the compounds, roving bands of individual soldiers, known as rookies, will try to eat you. They're especially hungry. Everyone in the Junkyard is an excellent fighter, skilled in multiple weapons and modes of battle. These people are also actually real people's data, imported into the program and wiped of all memories of their former lives - in a sense, they are real people. Slowly, now that the demon atma has been added to the program, these people are beginning to recall their former lives. However, the entire Junkyard is also unreal, composed completely of data in a computer bank. Anyone who enters the Junkyard through any worldhopping method is also turned into data for the length of time they are there. It constantly rains in the Junkyard, and the rain is also composed of data. The rain is literally the data being imported into the program by people in the real world, as they manipulate and make changes to the program. What does this mean? This means that characters who are skilled hackers - and I mean, not just good, I mean fantastic such that they can hack literally by the power of thought - can manipulate the fabric of the Junkyard. These people are referred to as Cyber Shaman. What the heck? How does that work? Anyone who has this ability, can change the Junkyard to suit their desires - in certain, limited ways. If they go too far with this, the Junkyard's security settings will intervene, Angel will get PMS, and your character will likely be ejected and wake up in their own world with a bad headache. If they're lucky. Such characters can create their own compound in an unneeded part of the world to their exact specifications, for example. They could make small changes to an existing structure within the Junkyard. They may be able to calm a maddened demon who is trying to eat them. They cannot: - Reduce an existing compound to rubble or change it in a significant way. - Actually control the actions or minds of anyone within the Junkyard. - Read minds. - Enter the Karma Temple without getting their asses kicked. - Stop the rain. - Enter Nirvana. - Reverse madness that has become too advanced. - Take over the Junkyard and rule it with an iron fist. - Do any of this subconsciously, or without meaning to Your character will need to figure out that they can manipulate the Junkyard, and then do it consciously. If you're not sure what your character can do, ask! So what if my character sucks with computers? To anyone who isn't a Cyber Shaman, the Junkyard will seem like a very strange, drab, dangerous place where it always rains. They likely will never notice that it's not real. Characters from the Junkyard who worldhop out will become real people not composed of data in any way. No one's abilities or physical properties will change in any way, regardless of whether they are in or out of the Junkyard. Only Cyber Shaman can perceive a difference. Please feel free to discuss this or ask me questions in this post.
I am Gale of the Embryon. If you leave a message for me, I will review it and respond when I am able to do so.

Gale's finger still felt odd without the Tag ring on it, but he was starting to get used to accessing the ATM to get money, and purchasing from vendors that were actual people rather than simply rooms full of equipment.

The underground complex that comprised the resistance's stronghold wasn't unlike the Embryon base. The only difference was that it was filled with old men and women and children, as well as able-bodied fighters. Also strange was that the fighters were humans. Humans who looked at the Embryon with open suspicion and fear, obviously terrified that they would turn on them and devour them.

Considering the stories that filtered through from the warfront, Gale couldn't blame them for their fear. It was inconvenient, however.

He could feel their eyes on him as he entered the Karma Terminal and logged into the community. If he had timed this correctly, Michael should arrive in the Terminal, and thus not frighten anyone by a sudden appearance. At least Michael was human.
Today we enter the Karma Temple. Sera will not stop us from reaching Nirvana any longer.

[Everyone looks exhausted and in pain, after a long series of difficult battles. Varin lies defeated on the floor before the five Embryon tribe leaders] [Argilla stands before the fallen man, angry at something he'd said earlier] Varin! What did you mean, I was devoured? [Varin gasps out his last breaths, but he's not dead yet] Don't call me... Don't call me by that name. I am a colonel... I am Colonel Beck. [Gale moves to stand beside Argilla, his green eyes curious and serious] You seem to know about Serph... Why is it...that you know about everyone except me? [Varin laughs bitterly, though it turns into a painful coughing fit] You're all fools...[Varin glares at Serph] You, [And then swings his gaze to Argilla] and you, [And now Cielo] and you too. Have you forgotten how that girl cast us into this hell? [The Embryon look at each other, puzzled, and Varin focuses his gaze upon Serph once again] Let me remind you, then. You... and I... We are all humans who died...in the same Nirvana you're all desperate to reach. [Argilla gasps in horror] That can't be... We died!? [Varin's body spasms violently. He is dying, but he looks at Sera, reaches out a trembling hand to point accusingly] That girl will...destroy the world... She is truly...the devil... [He collapses, and none of the Embryon notice Sera turn and walk out of the room with measured steps before the video cuts out completely]

[All five of the Embryon leaders are standing in the conference room of a brand new above-ground base. The previous one has been abandoned since it was found and breached by the Solids. Everyone's attention is on Gale, who looks particularly solemn.] I have bad news. It seems that Vishundha has been overrun. [Cielo reacts with shock] You said da Wolves would last longer dan dat! Though it defies probability, the fact is undeniable. And to make matters worse, the remaining members of Solids have been forcibly enlisted by the Brutes Tribe. At this rate, I am afraid they will destroy us all. [Cielo growls with frustration] Aww, gimme a break! Didn't Serph kill der boss...? Why did de Solids join de Brutes, huh? [Gale looks at Argilla instead of answering Cielo] Argilla... Tell me, would you follow Varin if he defeated Serph? Of course I wouldn't. Heat? [Heat doesn't appear to be paying attention] Huh? I'd take Serph's place. Exactly. The law states that members of a defeated Tribe are to obey the leader of the victorious Tribe. That rule has been disregarded. [Argilla looks at her own hand as if she doesn't recognize it] The law seems to be losing its effect on us. But, why could that be? [Gale's grey eyes sweep the room] Everyone has changed, just as you have. [Argilla glares at him suspiciously] It sounds to me like you knew about this all along. What were you planning to do? [Gale pushes a finger into the bridge of his nose] If the Wolves had held out, we could have fought the Brutes together. That is why this is so unfortunate. [A member of the Embryon rushed into the room and interrupts the meeting.] Boss! Lupa, from the Wolves.... He's asking to see you. [Gale turns to the man in surprise] Did you say Lupa? Where did he come from? [The newcomer shakes his head] Well, you wouldn't believe it if I told you. We have them detained at Svadhisthana. Let us go, Serph. [Serph nods and they all leave the room]
[The scene shifts in a burst of static. They are outside now, a group of strangers standing near an open grate that seems to lead down into a sewer system. The clear leader is a dark-skinned man with red dredlocks and warpaint on his face. Gale and Serph walk towards him] [Gale speaks first] State your business. [Lupa gazes at them coolly, but with determination] Will the Embryon assist us to defeat Varin? Under what conditions? [Lupa closed his eyes in contemplation. He is calm and resolute] Your leader will receive my head. In exchange, I ask you to treat my men fairly. [Gale slides out the knife hidden in his boot and brings his leg up and around. The blade stops touching the side of Lupa's neck and Gale stands frozen, balancing easily on one leg. Lupa didn't even flinch] [Argilla cries out with shock at the sudden and brutal move] Gale! [Gale still doesn't move, holding the bootknife to Lupa's throat] What assurance do we have that you are not here on Varin's behalf? [The Wolves by Lupa's side tighten their fists, ready for a fight, but Lupa holds out an arm to stop the impending confrontation.] I vow upon my honor. [Gale looks confused] Honour...? What is this "honour" you speak of? [Lupa gazes into Gale's eyes] I see it within you, as well. [But this doesn't enlighten Gale] I do not comprehend. How does one see such a thing? I can see it in your eyes. [Gale's eyes flashes green briefly once more. However, they returned to their old grayness again, and the video dissolves once more into static]

It was raining. But then, though Birkin wouldn't have known it, it always rained in the Junkyard.

The Embryon Compound was largely underground, but there were high walls around the area, patrolled by guards with wicked-looking automatic rifles. Gale stood in the gateway, under the gently fluttering flag - a scrap of fabric with a splash of orange paint across it - that denoted this Embryon territory.

Beyond the walls were piles of junk, a maze of debris. The debris had been cleared so that no one could approach the compound without being seen and killed.

Gale had instructed the guards not to shoot until they'd verified that any approaching men were actually enemies. If Birkin didn't get killed by rookies in the wasteland, he should arrive at any moment. He wondered if Birkin's eyes would glow like Michael's had done.

Gale stood in the large karma terminal in the Embryon's compound, waiting for Naoto to come to collect him. The room was the only one he could think of that had a screen like the kind Naoto had described, and while it was somewhat small, he was pretty sure people could climb in and out of it.

The room itself was dominated by the central console, which stood on a circular dias and lit in a red glow.

Holding the strap of his assault rifle, which was slung over his shoulder, Gale waited for his new orders.

It was raining. Of course, it always rained in the Junkyard. A length of cloth, splashed with a stripe of orange paint hung from a flagpole at the entrance to the Embryon's underground base. It flapped weakly in the breeze, weighted down with water.

Gale stood at the entrance, waiting. His blank, pupil-less silver eyes scanned the wastelands beyond the gate. He had an assault rifle slung over his back, but it was his only visible weapon.

Behind him, stairs descended into the upper reaches of the compound. A few soldiers patrolled the floor, and a couple of elevators were visible, which would provide access to the compound itself. It was grey, austere, military, but in a guerrilla, makeshift sort of way. The only colour were the splashes of orange paint on the walls, and the grey uniforms of the soldiers.
